column4: SSH question, is it possible to define either the use of public keys or passwords on a per account/user basis?
Do you want to limit the key people to key only?
what do you mean?
some people like disallowing password logins when using public keys, did you?
yes, I've disabled password authentication
I guess enabling password authentication and then using AllowUsers would be a OK solution? What do you think?

only thing I can think of for a mixed environment is to allow both.  The people who don't have keys obviously can't use them.  but then you run into the problem of allowing people with keys to log in with passwords.
yeah that just crossed my mind too, I only want people designated as "must have keys" to be able to login with keys (not passwords)
allowusers is only used for who can access at all, through whatever means.
Do the people with keys have admin access?
not perse
Since, if none of them could sudo, theoretically you could lock their accounts (I believe that won't affect the key based auth)
lock their accounts?
passwd -l account
Changes the password has to something that could never be generated (by inserting illegal characters)
that is, password hash.
It might lock them out of key based auth as well, I'm not sure.
let me try it out for a second, but this still doesn't sound ideal ;-)
No, I agree it doesn't.  You might ask in #ubuntu-server, or even try a ssh channel (#ssh? #openssh? they both exist, no idea re: activity in either)
thanks, I'll try those out ;)
took me a while but locking an account will result in "Your account has expired; please contact your system administrator" when connecting over SSH
just thought I'd let you know ;)
I know, (search up) but he said he saved in ~/.gpg so I thought he might have just saved something wrong
good find, looks like I was close :-)
